questions.text: All of the following are non-protein-coding RNA, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All eukaryotic cells have two major classes of RNA:
    • Protein-coding RNAs or mRNAs
    • Two forms of abundant non-protein-coding RNAs, delineated based on size:
      • The large ribosomal RNAs (rRNAs) and long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs)
      • Small noncoding transfer RNAs (tRNAs), the small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) and the micro and silencing RNAs (miRNAs and siRNAs).
  • mRNA carries genetic information from DNA to the cellular machinery responsible for protein synthesis, where it serves as a template for assembling amino acids into a specific protein-the final product of gene expression.
  • The mRNAs, rRNAs, and tRNAs are directly involved in protein synthesis, while the other RNAs participate in either mRNA splicing (snRNAs) or modulation of gene expression by altering mRNA function (mi/siRNAs) and/or expression (lncRNAs).
  • These RNAs differ in their diversity, stability, and abundance in cells.

Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) (Option A) helps in protein synthesis by providing a framework for protein synthesis.

Transfer RNA (tRNA) (Option B) helps in protein synthesis by transferring specific amino acids as per the code on mRNA during the synthesis of protein.

Small nuclear RNA (snRNA) (Option D) helps in protein splicing.

questions.text: Which of the following RNAs is present in an abundant amount in a cell?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ribosomal RNA is 80% of the total RNA in a cell, so it is the most abundant in a cell.

Messenger RNA (Option A) is 2 to 5% of total RNA in the cell.

Transfer RNA (Option B) is around 15% of the total RNA in the cell.

Micro RNA (Option D) is <1% of total RNA in cells.

choices.text: No efficient proofreading function during RNA synthesis
Primer is not involved in RNA synthesis
DNA synthesis occurs with 5-3 polarity, whereas RNA synthesis occurs with 3-5 polarity
U replaces T as the complementary base for A in RNA synthesis

questions.text: RNA synthesis is different from DNA synthesis in the following ways, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both DNA and RNA synthesis occur in the 5' to 3' direction; RNA synthesis does not occur in the 3' to 5' direction.

In summary, Option B is the exception because a primer is indeed involved in RNA synthesis, similar to DNA synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following forms of mammalian RNA polymerase enzyme is highly sensitive to the action of α-amanitin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

RNA Polymerase II is highly sensitive to the action of α-amanitin.

α-amanitin:

  • It is a peptide toxin derived from the mushroom ‘Amanita phalloides,' which is a specific differential inhibitor of the eukaryotic nuclear DNA-dependent RNA polymerases and, as such, has proven to be a powerful research tool.
  • α-amanitin blocks the translocation of RNA polymerase during phosphodiester bond formation.

RNA Polymerase I (Option A) is insensitive to the action of α-amanitin.

RNA Polymerase III (Option C) has intermediate sensitivity to the action of α-amanitin.

Reverse transcriptase (Option D): No action of α-amanitin on reverse transcriptase.

questions.text: Spliceosomes consist of all of the following small nuclear RNA, except,
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The spliceosome is a special multicomponent complex that converts the primary transcript into mature mRNA.

It consists of:

  • The primary transcript
  • Five small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs): U1, U2, U4, U5, and U6 (Options A, B, & D ruled out)
  • Over 60 proteins, many containing RRM (RNA recognition motif) and SR (serine-arginine) protein motifs

The snRNAs and RRM/SR-containing proteins together form small nuclear ribonucleoprotein (snRNP) complexes.

Sequence of spliceosome assembly and action:

  • U1 snRNP binds first by base pairing to the 5' exon-intron boundary.
  • U2 snRNP binds to the branch site, exposing the nucleophilic adenine (A) residue.
  • The U4/U5/U6 snRNP complex mediates ATP-dependent unwinding, disrupting the base pairing between U4 and U6 and releasing U4.
  • U6 snRNA then interacts with U2, then with U1, bringing together the 5'-splice site, branch point, and 3'-splice site.
  • U5 enhances this alignment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with pallor, jaundice, and abnormal enlargement of the liver and spleen. On investigation, he has low Hb and hypochromic microcytic anaemia. He was diagnosed with beta thalassemia major. Which of the following processes is most likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A defect in mRNA splicing can cause disease.
  • One of the first examples of the critical importance of accurate splicing was the discovery that one form of β-thalassemia, a disease in which the β-globin gene of haemoglobin is severely underexpressed, results from a nucleotide change at an exon-intron junction.
  • This mutation precludes the removal of the intron, altering the translational reading frame of β-globin mRNA, thereby blocking the β-chain protein production and hence haemoglobin.

mRNA capping (Option B): mRNA capping is a general process involved in stabilizing mRNA and initiating translation. Defects in capping are not specifically linked to beta thalassemia.

mRNA synthesis (Option C): mRNA synthesis (transcription) is a broad process. Beta thalassemia is more specifically related to the faulty processing of beta-globin mRNA rather than its synthesis.

U4 (Option D): U4 is one of the small nuclear RNAs involved in the spliceosome complex. While important in splicing, a defect in U4 alone is not the known cause of beta thalassemia. The disease relates to abnormal splicing of the beta-globin gene itself, not a universal spliceosome RNA defect.

questions.text: Below is an image of transfer RNA, which helps in the transfer of amino acids from the cytoplasm to the ribosome during protein synthesis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Transfer RNA

  • About 15% of the total RNA in the cell.
  • They are easily soluble, also k/a soluble RNA or sRNA.
  • They are present in the cytoplasm
  • General structure is similar to other RNA. Additionally have some typical structural characteristics.

Typical Structural Characteristics:

  • The smallest of the three major types of RNA molecule (73-93 nucleotides in length).
  • Contain some unusual bases (eg Dihydrouracil, Pseudouridine & hypoxanthine).
  • Have extensive internal base-pairing that produces a characteristic structure (Clover leaf-like structure).
  • In their structure, they have 5 different parts (5 arms), which differ in structure & function.
    • Acceptor Arm:
      • It carries the amino acid.
      • At the 3' End, it has 7 base pairs.
      • The end sequence is CCA-3'.
      • Each tRNA serves as an "adaptor" molecule that carries its specific amino acid-covalently attached to its 3'-end, to the site of protein synthesis
    • Anticodon Arm: (Option C)
      • Present at the opposite side of the acceptor arm.
      • It recognizes the codon present in mRNA.
      • It has base sequences complementary to mRNA codon. The specificity of tRNA is in anticodon sites.
    • DHU Arm (D arm): (Option D)
      • Named due to presence of a dihydrouridine (DHU) in this area.
      • It is a recognition site for the enzyme which adds amino acid to t RNA.
    • Pseudouridine Arm: (Option B)
      • Opposite to the DHU arm, named as it contains pseudouridine.
      • It is involved in binding tRNA to ribosomes
    • About 75% of tRNA molecules possess a short extra arm.

Functions of tRNA:

  • Transfer amino acids from cytoplasm to ribosome for protein synthesis; so k/a transfer RNA.
  • It recognizes the genetic code on mRNA, which specifies specific amino acids.
  • At least 20 species of tRNA molecules in every cell, at least one (and often several) corresponding to each of the 20 amino acids required for protein synthesis.
  • Specific tRNA carries its specific amino acid, which is then added in the growing polypeptide chain.

choices.text: Bind to the beta subunit of RNA polymerase to block the initiation of transcription
Binds to the DNA template and interferes with the movement of RNA polymerase along the DNA
Causes incorrect entry into chain causing chain termination

questions.text: Dactinomycin (known to biochemists as actinomycin D) was the first antibiotic to find therapeutic application in tumour chemotherapy. Which of the following describes its mechanism of action during RNA transcription?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dactinomycin (Actinomycin D) is an antibiotic derived from Streptomyces species that binds tightly to double-stranded DNA.

  • By intercalating between base pairs, it prevents the progression or movement of RNA polymerase along the DNA template, thereby inhibiting the elongation phase of RNA transcription.
  • This action blocks the synthesis of RNA chains, which is why it is effectively used as an anticancer drug.

Other inhibitors of transcription differ in their mechanisms:

  • Rifampicin binds to the beta subunit of prokaryotic RNA polymerase, blocking initiation of transcription.
  • Alpha amanitin, a mushroom toxin, specifically inactivates RNA polymerase II in eukaryotes.
  • Synthetic analogs like 3'-deoxyadenosine cause chain termination by incorrect nucleotide incorporation.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription is 5'-GTACTAG-3'. What is the base sequence of the RNA product?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The RNA product has a sequence that is complementary to the template strand and identical to the coding strand of DNA.
  • The RNA transcript has the same polarity (5'-3') as the coding strand but contains U rather than T.
  • Thus, the DNA template 5'-GTACTAG-3' would produce the RNA product 3'-CAUGAUC-5'or, written correctly in standard direction, 5'-CUAGUAC-3'.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with trouble walking to the paediatrician. He is diagnosed with DMD (Duchenne muscular dystrophy) by PCR. Genetic analysis shows that the patient's gene for the muscle protein dystrophin on the X chromosome contains a mutation in its promoter region. Which would be the most likely defective process in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mutations in the promoter typically prevent formation of the RNA polymerase II transcription complex, resulting in a decrease in the initiation of mRNA synthesis during transcription.
  • Translation is the synthesis of protein from mRNA.
  • A mutation in promoter regions does not lead to any problem during translation or post-translational modifications. (Option A & B)
  • A deficiency of dystrophin mRNA will result in a deficiency in the production of the dystrophin protein.
  • Post-transcriptional modifications like capping, splicing, and tailing defects are not a consequence of promoter mutations. (Option D)

questions.text: A mutation in which of the following sequences in eukaryotic mRNA will affect post-translational modification of messenger RNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • AAUAA recognition sequence is for addition of poly A tail during post transcriptional modification of messenger RNA.
  • Poly(A) tails are added to the 3' end of mRNA molecules in a posttranscriptional processing step.
  • The mRNA is first cleaved about 20 nucleotides downstream from an AAUAA recognition sequence.
  • Another enzyme, poly(A) polymerase, adds a poly(A) tail which is subsequently extended to as many as 200 A residues.
  • The poly(A) tail both protects the 3' end of mRNA from 3' → 5' exonuclease attack and facilitates translation

CCA (Option A) is added to the 3'-end of transfer RNA by nucleotidyl transferase.

CAAT (Option B) and TATAAA (Option D) are sequences found in promoters for RNA polymerase II.

questions.text: The major product of RNA Polymerase I in eukaryotes is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ribosomal RNA is a product of RNA Polymerase I.

(Option A) Transfer RNA is a product of RNA Polymerase III.

(Option B) Messenger RNA is a product of RNA Polymerase II.

(Option D) Micro RNA is a product of RNA Polymerase II.
